step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with erectile dysfunction, buttock pain relieved by rest (claudication), weak femoral pulses, and risk factors (diabetes, smoking, hypertension). These findings align with aortoiliac atherosclerosis, which causes reduced blood flow to the lower extremities and pelvis. Document [1] describes Lériche syndrome as a triad of erectile dysfunction, claudication, and diminished pulses, with risk factors matching the patient's history. Document [9] links severe PAD to erectile dysfunction and weak pulses. The combination of symptoms and risk factors points to atherosclerotic disease of the aortoiliac region as the most specific etiology.
